data.title: Improving Particle Editor
data.body:
I'm trying to improve particle editor with these changes:
- Adding grid with option to hide it
- Gizmo now always visible in the left corner
- Change particle preview viewport camera to behave more predictably

![particle_editor_grid](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5253453/11419690/a829bed4-945b-11e5-980d-83afda49dbee.png)

There are some hacks while I implement this, like:
- Aspect ratio of preview viewport is always returning value of 1 in the first frame, so I decided to manually set aspect ratio.
- Camera node euler angle is returning vector of zero in first frame, so I decided to hardcoded global camera rotation variable in first frame.

I'm not sure if those are bugs, maybe it's because particle editor isn't immediately visible when starting Urho3D editor.

What do you guys think?

data.title: always provide a default ResourcePrefixPaths
data.body:
When trying to migrate the Urho3D Sample Platformer to Urho3D 1.5+ https://github.com/gawag/Urho-Sample-Platformer/issues/12 I've noticed that it must now contend with the new means of handling resource prefix paths.  The Setup() function in Urho3D\Source\Samples\Sample.inl has an example:

```
    // Construct a search path to find the resource prefix with two entries:
    // The first entry is an empty path which will be substituted with program/bin directory -- this entry is for binary when it is still in build tree
    // The second entry is a relative path from the installed program/bin directory to the asset directory -- this entry is for binary when it is in the Urho3D SDK installation location
    if (!engineParameters_.Contains("ResourcePrefixPaths"))
        engineParameters_["ResourcePrefixPaths"] = ";../share/Urho3D/Resources";
```

This code is borne as a solution to CMake build and installation problems.  It's not generally applicable to all possible uses of Urho3D, meaning, people who just use an Urho3D binary and aren't interested in using CMake for their own code.  That may sound like a corner case, but my point is the code is more about "contending with CMake" than using Urho3D.  Pedagogically, it would be easier for people to write simple code to get going with Urho3D, if they didn't have to worry about such things.

This could be accomplished by establishing a convention, that Urho3D will search the binary directory for resources _by default_.  The programmer could still alter this default behavior however he likes.  So, Urho3D would initialize ResourcePrefixPaths to "".  This eliminates the need for the following line:

```
    if (!engineParameters_.Contains("ResourcePrefixPaths"))
```

as by default it will always contain that.  Then provide something like:

```
engineParameters_["ResourcePrefixPaths"].Append("../share/Urho3D/Resources")
```

or even more tersely

```
engineParameters_["ResourcePrefixPaths"] += "../share/Urho3D/Resources"
```

if you like that sort of style.  I didn't look up whether engineParameters_ can do all those sorts of things, I figure you get the idea if it's relevant.

The pedagogical advantage is the user now has to do nothing if their code is simple and they didn't want to worry about installs, or if their install is simple and didn't need a parallel ../bin ../share style directory structure.  And if they do need to do something, they have to do less.

I think the pedagogy is important to sustaining the ecology of a 3d engine.  Developers get _real bored_ of trying to keep up with engine changes _real quick_.  For instance the Urho3D Sample Platformer developer has pretty much fallen off the radar in recent weeks.  He made some changes for some earlier bugs I filed, but then when he saw the 1.5 difficulties he seemed to throw up his hands and vanish.  I've been hoping that showing what he needed to do to move the code forwards would keep him from giving up.  I myself have had to exercise a certain amount of discipline as I don't actually have his code working yet, just built.  I'm having to slug through those very CMake build issues I mentioned above, and I can see why most developers wouldn't relish the complications such build issues bring.

A few years ago, I did a major inventory of the Ogre3D engine ecology.  They had listed numerous projects on their website that used their engine.  Well, as I worked through each and every last one of them, I found that the vast majority of them were bitrotted and abandoned.  I would say only 25% were actually viable as "code I'd currently inflict on people I wanted to keep as friends."  I moved all their project descriptions around and put the abandoned projects on a sort of graveyard page.  I was trying to give them a bit of a marketing facelift so they'd be putting their best foot forwards, so that code / projects / samples that actually worked and were worth looking at, would be front and center.  This taught me a lot about what happens to downstream code, generationally speaking.  Changes to an engine kill code.  I realize that Urho3D is under rather active development so some of this is unavoidable.  But I feel strongly that when it is possible, samples should be _easy_ for developers to write, and easy to migrate between versions.  Otherwise it all becomes a huge PITA and in the real world, people give up and move on with their lives.

Oh, and after doing that huge exercise which took me about a month, I concluded there wasn't enough "worth it" with Ogre3D to use it for anything.  One particular problem is it saw itself as only a 3D engine, not a game engine.  That made the ecology even harder to sustain.  For instance, it didn't bless any scripting languages.  Bindings to sane things like Lua were third party and bitrotted.  One reason I became interested in Urho3D is you _did_ bless a standard inventory of sane stuff.

Someone else did what needed to be done with Ogre3D, and that became the NeoAxis engine.  Which cost money.  Could easily have been an open source $0 project with a different developer attitude.

data.title: Playback finish events
data.body:
Provide events sent through the component's node for following situations:
- Animation playback finishes or loops
- Sound playback finishes
- (Oneshot) particle emitter playback finishes and all particles are gone

The last two represent situations where a "oneshot" effect node can be removed by the program logic. 

After providing these, the SoundSource autoremove mechanism can be marked deprecated, as it's the only place where the engine would automatically remove a component on its own, and feels out of place considering the rest of the API.

data.title: vs2010_sse_alignment_workaround
data.body: Work around VS2010 compiler bug with SSE and copy construction/assignment misalignment. Closes #1044.

data.title: vs2015_ucomige_ss_workaround
data.body: Work around bug #1053 (https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/2053175) by replacing the SSE1 specific _mm_ucomige_ss() with SSE2 specific _mm_cvtsi128_si32(_mm_castps_si128(c)) == -1. Given that URHO3D_SSE is targeting SSE2, this workaround has no drawbacks. Closes #1053.

data.title: Not able to run tests on AppVeyor
data.body:
This is a follow up from #1047.

Cause: Although AppVeyor VM image has been setup with a "display" on session 1 but that display is not "attached to desktop", so SDL library terminates the app with this error log entry `No displays available` in a dialog box causing CTest to wait indefinitely.

When using RDP to remotely login into the VM while it is running, the login session (session 1) would get a desktop and consequently causing the display on session 1 to attach to desktop as well. So, when CTest is invoked later, all the tests could complete successfully. However, we could not run the tests in this way as there is no easy way to automatic another process to perform the remote login via RDP.

data.title: Physics Component "over sensitive"
data.body:
I'm using over sensitive here because there is no better term to describe it... I made a table and added different collision shapes to its legs and the top. When I shoot a sphere which has a rigid body through the legs of the table, the table makes a slight movement as if it was brushed by the sphere even though the sphere passed through without contact...
Here is an image showing the collision shapes of the table as designed using thhe Editor:
![table_outlined](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6633428/11326336/764ddacc-9167-11e5-8d97-800913b5c911.jpg)

And here is when I shoot a sphere through the legs:
![with_sphere](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6633428/11326349/9968fe56-9167-11e5-9ac7-ced65fe546f8.jpg)

I equally noticed something similar in the 13_Ragdolls sample. When a a jack has been shot down, shooting spheres very close to the body but without contact with the collision shapes also gives these effect. I tried this out using  minGW and Visual Studio 2013 (all on windows) and I still got the same effect

data.title: Why all the example extend the class Sample?
data.body:
As a newbie it makes learning really hard..

I can't compile a single simple hello world on my own using clion, i just want to display a window

What i'm doing wrong ?

``` cmake
# Set project name
project (theRoguer3D)

# Set minimum version
cmake_minimum_required (VERSION 2.8.6)
if (COMMAND cmake_policy)
    cmake_policy (SET CMP0003 NEW)
    if (CMAKE_VERSION VERSION_GREATER 2.8.12 OR CMAKE_VERSION VERSION_EQUAL 2.8.12)
        # INTERFACE_LINK_LIBRARIES defines the link interface
        cmake_policy (SET CMP0022 NEW)
    endif ()
    if (CMAKE_VERSION VERSION_GREATER 3.0.0 OR CMAKE_VERSION VERSION_EQUAL 3.0.0)
        # Disallow use of the LOCATION target property - therefore we set to OLD as we still need it
        cmake_policy (SET CMP0026 OLD)
        # MACOSX_RPATH is enabled by default
        cmake_policy (SET CMP0042 NEW)
    endif ()
endif ()


# Set CMake modules search path
set (CMAKE_MODULE_PATH /usr/local/share/Urho3D/CMake/Modules)
# Include Urho3D Cmake common module
include (Urho3D-CMake-common)
# Find Urho3D library
find_package (Urho3D REQUIRED)
include_directories (${URHO3D_INCLUDE_DIRS})

# Set source files
set (SOURCE_FILES GameClient.cpp GameClient.h)

# Define dependency libs
set (INCLUDE_DIRS ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR})

# Define target name
set (TARGET_NAME theRoguer3D)
# Define source files
define_source_files ()
# Setup target with resource copying
setup_main_executable ()

TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES (theRoguer3D "/usr/local/lib/Urho3D/libUrho3D.so")
```

``` cpp
#include <Urho3D/Engine/Application.h>

#ifndef CPPTEST_GAMECLIENT_H
#define CPPTEST_GAMECLIENT_H

using namespace Urho3D;

class GameClient : public Application
{
public:
    GameClient(Context *context);
};

#endif //CPPTEST_GAMECLIENT_H
```

``` cpp
#include "GameClient.h"

GameClient::GameClient(Context *context) :
        Application(context)
{
}
```

data.title: Render to a texture with antialiasing
data.body:
Add the ability to render to a texture(RenderSurface) with multisample antialiasing, please.
I know there is the FXAA filter, but it does not always provide an acceptable quality.

data.title: Add RemoveViewport() to RenderSurface
data.body:
While using SetViewport() with nullptr should remove the SharedPtr ref count (does it? std::shared_ptr does), it requires the user to inspect the implementation to make sure how memory is going to be managed.

Having a RemoveViewport(index) would abstract away memory management questions like "Does it store raw or shared pointers to the viewports?" and "If I set it to nullptr, would the ref count go down?".

data.title: D3D11 shader interpolator order bug when using point lights and VCol techniques
data.body: Shader compiler messes up the interpolator order; needs tweaking of the LitSolid shader source to make sure the order is kept.

data.title: Misc. minor issues in the build system and its extensions for Travis and AppVeyor
data.body:
- Android Intel Atom CI build (both 32 and 64-bit) fail to create build artifact for STATIC lib type. Possible cause: Travis out of memory. [done]
- Since upgrading the OSX build environment to Xcode7.1, the Urho3D_universal target exceeds the 50 minutes build time limit for iOS 64-bit CI build. Possible cause: slower VM where Xcode7.1 resides or the universal binary for Xcode7.1 has too many archs (yet to be verified). [done]
- Fail to create mirror CI branches when commit message contains quotation mark. Cause: the string interpolation does not perform the necessary escape. [done]
- Packaging for Emscripten does not include `Urho3D.js` and `Urho3D.js.data` (which are generated when EMSCRIPTEN_SHARE_DATA build option is being used). Cause: packaging bug. [done]
- Build artifacts from CI build using Makefile have an incompatible CPU instruction with user's CPU. Cause: deployment target in the CI builds using Makefile is erroneously left to its default value 'native' where Travis CI VM image probably has a "funky" CPU type that is incompatible with common users have. [done]
- Fail to run tests on AppVeyor. Cause: Although AppVeyor VM image has been setup with a "display" on session 1 but that display is not "attached to desktop", so SDL library terminates the app with this error log entry `No displays available`.
- Build artifact (package) generation failure does not stop the build process at the moment. In the past the build artifacts are viewed only as a by-product. However, in doing so it is too late for us to realize we have problem in packaging when performing an actual release tag. [done]

data.title: Better integration with SDL's own CMakeLists.txt
data.body: This is a follow up from discussion in #876.

data.title: 2D Physics issue with Z coord
data.body:
Hey @aster2013 using a dynamic RigidBody2D and a StaticSprite2D with 3D coords (considering Z != 0), physics still works on Z=0 and all the dynamic processing forces Z=0 which is not what we want.

I tested that in the editor (remove .txt extension)
[Test2DPhysics.xml.txt](https://github.com/urho3d/Urho3D/files/36845/Test2DPhysics.xml.txt)

If you press Play you see all the physics happens at Z=0

data.title: Crash with URHO3D_SSE=1 on VS2010 in release mode
data.body:
Application crashes to null pointer references after SSE optimized math operations (e.g. Matrix3x4 multiply) when compiled with Visual Studio 2010 release mode.

Possibly a compiler bug. If no other solution is readily possible, SSE could be disabled by default on VS2010 (URHO3D_SSE=0)

data.title: iOS build tree configuration error on Travis-CI with CMake 3.4 and Xcode7.1
data.body:
Log from the recent iOS build tree configuration.

```
CMake Error at /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.4.0/share/cmake/Modules/Platform/Darwin.cmake:76 (message):
  CMAKE_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET is '10.10' but CMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT:
   "iphoneos"
  is not set to a MacOSX SDK with a recognized version.  Either set
  CMAKE_OSX_SYSROOT to a valid SDK or set CMAKE_OSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET to
  empty.
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /usr/local/Cellar/cmake/3.4.0/share/cmake/Modules/CMakeSystemSpecificInformation.cmake:36 (include)
  CMakeLists.txt:3 (project)
CMake Error: Internal CMake error, TryCompile configure of cmake failed
-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
```

CMake just newly released 3.4 and it was being installed by our install script as the new release reaches homebrew repository. There is either a bug in the way we configure the iOS build tree which only manifested itself in this latest release; or there is a bug in the CMake 3.4 itself. To be investigated.

data.title: Build SDL with PulseAudio if available
data.body: Using ALSA sound on Linux results in 100% CPU usage for one of the threads.  PulseAudio behaves better on my machine.  The sample 14_SoundEffects goes down to around 20% CPU usage when PulseAudio is used instead.

data.title: Unresolved external symbol
data.body:
I builded and compiled 1.5 version with URHO3D_D3D11 set to 1, fixed everything that was needed fixing according to IntelliSense. But now I have unresolved external symbols. Those are: D3D11CreateDevice(), __IID_IDXGIAdapter, __IID_IDXGIFactory, __IID_IDXGIDevice, __IID_IDXGIDevice1, __IID_ID3D11Texture2D, __IID_ID3D11ShaderReflection.
I suspect that I am missing some DX11 libraries, but I'm not sure.
Please, help me, if you can.

data.title: Add Mutex.TryAcquire().
WIN32 is used instead of _WIN32
data.body:
Core\main.h contains the convenience macro DEFINE_MAIN so that a cross-platform main function can be used by consumers of Urho3D.  It relies on the macro WIN32 for correct Windows behavior, but the correct macro for VS 2015 is _WIN32.  https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/b0084kay.aspx  It seems WIN32 existed historically but has since been depreciated.  I haven't found a definitive reference for when that happened.  That MSDN page has a tab for looking at documentation for different compiler versions.  The earliest available is VS .NET 2003, which still shows _WIN32 as the correct macro.  So, we at least know the "best practice" has been the same for 12 years.

The consequence for a consuming application, such as Urho Sample Platformer, is DEFINE_MAIN doesn't work.  One ends up with main() instead of WinMain().

data.title: Batching control or fake instancing
data.body:
I am not sure if this is implemented already but if we have the same nodes with the same materials without any overrides except transform, would it be possible to send them in one batch saving draw calls? I am referring to a method similar to fake instancing from this article: http://carloscarrasco.com/faking-mesh-instancing-in-opengl-es-20.html 
It would be quite beneficial for older devices that does not support hardware instancing. In general are there any plans for exposing the batching control?

data.title: Node paste in editor can cause incorrect transform
data.body:
When a node containing e.g. a static model and scaling is copy-pasted while keeping the original node selected, the pasted node ends up parented to the original, but the scaling is not recalculated for the new parent, which results in the copy being doubly scaled.

Possible solutions:
- Always paste to the original node's parent
- Recalculate the transform

data.title: Backport XRandR and memory leak fix
data.body:
XRandR support is broken in SDL 2.0.3.  This was fixed in head a few months ago.

data.title: Process doesn't end on Windows because of UAC virtualization
data.body:
urho application's process may not end for some users on Windows if they don't have write permission.
That happens because of UAC virtualization:
https://decibel.ni.com/content/groups/windows-7/blog/2009/10/02/uac-virtualization-and-how-it-affects-your-installers

If Urho is trying to write something to Urho3D.log on shutdown and doesn't quit until that happens that could be the reason for the process not ending.
